questions.question: Question 1: What is the Lancefield grouping of -hemolytic-streptococci based on?
questions.explanation:
Lancefield grouping of -hemolytic-streptococci is based on group-specific carbohydrate C antigen 
present on the cell wall. He classified them into 20 serological types from Group-A to Group V 
except for I and J. Group A -hemolytic streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes) are further classified by 
Griffith typing based on protein antigens (M, T, R) present on the cell surface. 103 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: An elderly diabetic lady presented with swelling and pain of her right leg following a skin 
biopsy. She was febrile at the time of examination and hemorrhagic bullae with necrosis of 
the surrounding skin were noted on her leg. Gram staining of the pus collected from the 
bullae is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely organism causing this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of necrotizing fasciitis which is most commonly 
caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A -hemolytic streptococcus). Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressive inflammatory infection of the fascia, with secondary 
necrosis of the subcutaneous tissues. It has also been referred to as Meleney ulcer, acute dermal 
gangrene, hospital gangrene, suppurative fasciitis, and synergistic necrotizing cellulitis. The 
source of the infection is either the skin, with organisms introduced into the tissue through 
trauma, or the bowel flora, with organisms released during abdominal surgery. The onset of symptoms is usually quite acute and is marked by severe pain at the site of 
involvement, malaise, fever, chills, and a toxic appearance. The affected limb is edematous with 
the overlying skin turning dusky with mottled erythema and the development of hemorrhagic 
bullae. This is a surgical emergency as the condition is rapidly fatal. Treatment of the condition includes: • Surgical intervention is the major therapeutic modality in cases of necrotizing fasciitis. • Antibiotics- penicillin (1-4 million U IV q4h) plus clindamycin (600-900 mg IV q8h). The following image shows surgical debridement being done for a case of necrotising fasciitis. 104 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: A 7-year-old child was brought in by her mother to the OPD with complaints of fever, sore 
throat, and a scarlatiniform rash. A throat swab was taken and sent to the lab for culture on 
blood agar. Which of the following factors is responsible for the zones of hemolysis seen in 
the culture below?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario o a patient with fever, sore throat, and a scarlatiniform rash is suggestive 
of scarlet fever caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. Streptolysin S is the factor responsible for 
the zones of hemolysis seen around streptococcal colonies on blood agar. Streptococci produces two hemolysins: • Streptolysin O is called so because it is oxygen-labile. It is also heat-labile and it has specific 
cardiotoxic and leucotoxic activity. • Streptolysin S is called so because it is soluble in serum. It is also oxygen-stable hemolysin. It is 
a protein but is not antigenic. The following image shows blood agar with colonies of streptococci with hemolytic zones around 
them: 105 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following organisms produces superantigen?
questions.explanation:
Streptococcus pyogenes produces streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin (SPE), which is a superantigen. Superantigens are protein toxins that stimulate large numbers of T cells, irrespective of antigen 
specificity. They bind to the class II MHC molecule outside the peptide-binding groove and V 
region of the TCR. Some examples of superantigens are staphylococcal enterotoxins, toxic shock 
syndrome toxin, and group A streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin. The below image shows the binding of superantigen to T-cell receptor.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following types of streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins is bacteriophage mediated? 97 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins type A and type C are bacteriophage-mediated toxins. The streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin(SPE) is so named because the primary effect of the toxin is 
the induction of fever. It is also known as erythrogenic toxin because its intra-dermal injection 
into susceptible individuals produced an erythematous reaction (Dick Test). There are 3 types of streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins namely: • type A - phage mediated. • type B - chromosome mediated. • type C - phage mediated.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is a streptococcal toxin responsible for connective tissue breakdown?
questions.explanation:
106 
Sold by @itachibot Hyaluronidase is the streptococcal toxin responsible for connective tissue breakdown. Hyaluronidase or spreading factor is expressed by non-capsulated strains of Streptococcus 
pyogenes, such as M type 4 and 22. It acts by cleaving hyaluronic acid, which is present in the 
connective tissue, epithelial, and neural tissues. This results in the spread of infection along the 
intercellular space.

questions.question: Question 7: Which streptococcal antigen cross reacts with myocardium?
questions.explanation:
Antibodies to the cell wall M antigen present on the Streptococcus cross-reacts with a similar 
myocardial antigen. This cross-reaction with myocardium is the cause of acute rheumatic fever.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 12-year-old child presented with a sore throat for 3 days. Which of the following medium is 
used to culture the throat swab?
questions.explanation:
Blood agar is the preferred culture media as it is used for the culture and isolation of 
Streptococcus pyogenes which is the most common cause of sore throat. The selective medium for Streptococcus pyogenes is Crystal violet blood agar and the transport 
media for this organism is Pikes medium.

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following organisms show beta-hemolysis on blood agar, resistance to 
bacitracin, and a positive CAMP test? 98 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Streptococcus agalactiae is a group B streptococci that shows -hemolysis on blood agar, 
is resistant to bacitracin, and gives a positive CAMP test. The CAMP test is used to identify group B -hemolyitic-streptococci based on their ability to 
form CAMP factor. This factor causes synergistic hemolysis with -hemolysin formed 
by Staphylococcus aureus, when Streptococcus agalactiae is inoculated perpendicular to a streak 
of Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar. This produces the characteristic arrow-head zone of 
hemolysis. The below image shows a positive CAMP test. 107

questions.question:
Question 10: A child presents to the OPD with an infective skin lesion over his leg. On microscopic 
examination of the pus from the lesion, gram-positive cocci in chains are visualized and pus 
culture shows -haemolytic colonies on blood agar. Which of the following tests can be 
performed to identify the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
 hemolytic colonies on blood agar with gram-positive cocci in chains seen on microscopy suggest 
the organism is a -hemolytic streptococcus. Bacitracin sensitivity is used to differentiate between 
group A and group B -hemolytic streptococci. Group A: Bacitracin-sensitive (S. pyogenes) Group B: Bacitracin-resistant (S. agalactiae) Options A & B: Bile solubility and optochin sensitivity are used to differentiate Streptococcus 
pneumoniae and viridans streptococci. They are both  hemolytic on blood agar but some species 
of viridans streptocci are non hemolytic. Option D: Catalase test is used to differentiate streptococcus and staphylococcus. Staphylococcus 
appear as clusters of gram positive cocci on microscopy and not chains. 108 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following bacteria is associated with the causation of colorectal carcinoma, 
rectal polyp, endocarditis and septicaemia and is pyrrolidinyl arylamidase test negative?
questions.explanation:
Streptococcus gallolyticus is associated with the causation of colorectal CA, rectal polyp, 
endocarditis, and septicemia and is pyrrolidinyl arylamidase test (PYR test) negative. Streptococcus gallolyticus, formerly called Streptococcus bovis, is a non-enterococcal Group D 
streptococci. It is bile insoluble, esculin hydrolysis positive, PYR negative and shows no growth in 
6.5% NaCl.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following organisms can survive up to 60°C, is PYR positive, and can grow on 
media with 6.5% NaCl?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, Enterococcus feacalis can survive up to 60°C, is PYR test positive, and 
can grow in the presence of 6.5% NaCl. Enterococci have the following features: • Formation of tiny deep pink colonies on MacConkey’s medium • Survives at 600C for 30 minutes. • Growth in the presence of 40 % bile, 6.5% sodium chloride at pH 9.6. • PYR (Pyrrolidonyl Arylamidase) positive • Esculin hydrolysis is positive. • Usually nonhemolytic, but may show  or  hemolysis. Option A: Streptococcus pyogenes is a delicate organism, easily destroyed by heat (54°C for 30 
min), PYR positive. Option B: Streptococcus agalactiae is PYR test negative. Option D: Streptococcus pneumoniae are readily destroyed by heat (52°C for 15 min).

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient admitted to an ICU spiked a fever and his blood culture was positive for 
gram-positive cocci in chains, which are catalase-negative. He was being given ceftazidime 
and amikacin via a central venous line for the past week. Following this, you started him on 
vancomycin but his blood culture remained positive for the same organism even after 2 weeks 
of therapy. Which of the following is the most likely organism causing the infection?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) infection. Gram-positive cocci in chains that are catalase-negative suggest that the organism belongs to 
Streptococcaceae family. Positive culture after 2 weeks of vancomycin therapy suggests resistance 
to vancomycin. Option A: Streptococcus pyogenes are sensitive to vancomycin and are not commonly implicated 
in central venous line infections. Option B: Viridans streptococci are usually mouth commensals and are sensitive to vancomycin. Option D: Coagulase-negative staphylococci are gram-positive cocci in clusters which 
are catalase-positive. Hence, they can be ruled out. 109 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: Oral examination of a young patient shows the following finding. Which bacteria belonging to 
viridans group is most commonly implicated in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The above image shows dental caries which are commonly caused by Streptococcus mutans. 
It belongs to the viridans group/ -hemolytic streptococci. Streptococcus mutans breaks down the dietary sucrose producing acid and a tough adhesive 
dextran. The acid damages dentine while the dextrans bind together with food debris, epithelial 
cells, mucus, and bacteria to form dental plaques, leading to formation of dental caries.

questions.question:
Question 15: 100 
Sold by @itachibot A 49-year-old man presented with high-grade fever, cough and shortness of breath. On 
examination, he was febrile, tachypneic and tachycardic. A chest X-ray was performed which 
is shown in the image. What is the single most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history and the X-ray showing right lower lobe consolidation is strongly 
suggestive of lobar pneumonia, most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae (>95 % 
of cases). Lobar pneumonia is an acute exudative inflammation of an entire pulmonary lobe. The below 
image shows the histopathological picture of lobar pneumonia.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 70-year-old male presented with fever, chills and cough associated with chest pain. His 
sputum sample was sent for culture on blood agar which showed the presence of  -hemolytic 
colonies the following day. Which of the following best describes the organism likely 
implicated here?

options.a: Gram-positive cocci in short chains, catalase negative and bile resistant
options.b: Gram-positive cocci in pairs, catalase negative and bile soluble
options.c: Gram-positive cocci in clusters, catalase positive and coagulase positive
options.d: Gram-positive cocci in clusters, catalase positive and coagulase negative

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the growth of alpha-hemolytic colonies from the sputum of the 
patient are strongly suggestive of pneumococcal pneumonia. Pneumococci are gram-positive cocci 
in pairs, catalase negative, and bile soluble. The image below shows Gram positive cocci in pairs. bile solubility, and catalase reaction. 110 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows positive bile solubility test shown by Streptococcus pneumoniae. The below image shows catalse test. 111

questions.question:
Question 17: Quellung reaction is used to demonstrate 
. 101 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Quellung reaction is used to demonstrate the capsule of streptococci. Quellung reaction (Quellung = swelling): • A suspension of pneumococci is mixed on a slide with a drop of type-specific antiserum and a 
loop full of methylene blue solution. • In the presence of homologous antiserum, the capsule becomes apparently swollen, sharply 
delineated and refractile. • The Quellung test can be done directly with sputum from acute pneumonia cases. The below image shows the swollen capsule of pneumococci following the addition of homologous 
antiserum. 112 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following factors is responsible for the draughtsman appearance of 
pneumococcal colonies?
questions.explanation:
The factor responsible for the draughtsman appearance of pneumococcal colonies is autolysin. When pneumococci are incubated on blood agar for a prolonged duration, the resultant colonies 
are surrounded with concentric rings and have a central umbonation. This appearance of 
pneumococcal colonies is known as carrom coin appearance or draughtsman appearance. Autolysin is an amidase enzyme produced by pneumococci that cleaves peptidoglycan, leading to 
the autolysis of cells. It is also responsible for the bile solubility of pneumococci. The below image shows the characteristic draughtsman appearance of pneumococcal colonies.

questions.question:
Question 19: In a splenectomized patient, there is an increased risk of infection by all capsulated 
organisms. Which of the following is least likely to cause an infection in such patients?
questions.explanation:
In splenectomized patients, there is an increased risk of infection by capsulated organisms such as 
Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Klebsiella pneumoniae. Staphylococcus 
aureus does not have a capsule and so poses no increased risk to these individuals. The phagocytosis of capsulated organisms is prevented by their capsule. Thus, the body's main 
defence against these organisms is the spleen. Certain components called opsonins attach to these capsulated organisms, and then they are 
delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of 
splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible 
to infection from these bacteria.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following statements is true about the pneumococcal vaccine?
questions.explanation:
113 
Sold by @itachibot Pneumococcal polyvalent vaccine PPSV23 is indicated in splenectomised patients. There are two kinds of polyvalent pneumococcal vaccines: • Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine - PPSV23 • It is indicated in splenectomized patients, sickle cell disease, immunocompromised patients, and 
patients above 65 years of age. • CDC currently recommends the administration of one additional dose of PPSV23 at least 5 years 
after the last dose. • Children younger than 2 years old should not get this vaccine since they fail to mount an 
adequate response. • Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine- • It includes PCV10 and PCV13. • It is indicated in children less than 2 years. 114 
Sold by @itachibot Staphylococci
